workflow.name: Talos Weekly Threat Roundup Blog Investigation
workflow.title: Talos Weekly Threat Roundup Blog Investigation

properties.name: retry_interval
properties.description:
This is the time interval between each retry to check whether the JSON file has become available.

Default is 3600 seconds (1 hour).

properties.name: joined_hashes
properties.description: This variable will contain all the hashes from File, Mutex and Registry

properties.name: max_number_retry_iterations
properties.description: Please note that each retry means 1 hour

properties.name: webex_bot_token
properties.description: This is the bot token for Webex Teams

properties.name: talos_blog_uri
properties.description:
Please insert the relative part of the URI in this format:

/YYYY/MM/YYYYMMDD-tru.json_.txt

properties.name: email_recipients
properties.description: emails for notifications (comma separated)

The playbook steps:

1.	Build the URI to retrieve the JSON file
2.	Retry mechanism is implemented to check every retry_interval whether URI has become available
3.	An https request is carried out to retrieve TALOS Weekly Roundup hosted IOCs, store in a table
4.	Communicate via Email&Webex Teams that the Talos Weekly Threat Roundup automatic investigation has started. 
5.	Extract IOCs - for each Threat, extract the IOCs from JSON and store into a variable
6.	Parse IOCs - from raw text in the variable
7.	Verdict IOCs - if an IOC has got a clean Verdict then is omitted
7.	Enrich IOCs - find any global sightings and local sightings/targets
8.	A table is created with an entry for each module that has answered
10.	Share Targets - For each module that replied back, post on Webex Teams and send an email
11.	Case Management â€“ In case targets are found a new casebook is created
12.	In case targets have not been found, an informational message is sent out
properties.display_name: Talos Weekly Threat Roundup Blog Investigation

actions.name: While Loop
actions.title: Check and retry if the weekly blog has not been published

properties.description:
As a first step, we check whether the Talos Roundup blog has been published for the current week. Remember that Talos use to publish the blog on Fridays. 

We set a while loop, checking every hour for max_number_iteration (input value, required, by default 24) if the blog has been published. If after the max_number_iteration the blog has not been published, the while loop terminates the workflow and a message is sent (email or Webex teams) informing that the max number of retries has been reached, the workflow has been terminated and therefore a manual run of the workflow is required.
properties.display_name: Check and retry if the weekly blog has not been published

properties.description: Check if the max number of iteration has been reached. This is a "cosmetic" check since the real control is done later in the condition "Yes, max number reached, send messages and exit workflow".

actions.title: Check if the URI has been provided as Input to the Workflow

blocks.title: If no URI provided as manual input to the workflow

properties.display_name: If no URI provided as manual input to the workflow

actions.title: Build the TALOS Weekly Roundup URI (latest)

properties.display_name: Build the TALOS Weekly Roundup URI (latest)

actions.name: Group
actions.title: Build the Current Week portion of the URI

properties.display_name: Build the Current Week portion of the URI

actions.name: Execute Python Script
actions.title: Build Talos Roundup blog URI (current week)

properties.description: This python script builds the part of the URI taking into account the current date of run.
properties.display_name: Build Talos Roundup blog URI (current week)
properties.script:
import datetime
from datetime import timedelta
dt = datetime.date.today()
y = dt.weekday() 
if y == 4:
#       offset = 14
    offset = 0
elif y == 5:
    offset = 1
elif y == 6:
    offset = 2
else:
    offset = y + 3
#       offset = y + 17
x = timedelta(days=offset)
last_blog_publish_date = dt - x
month = last_blog_publish_date.strftime("%m")
year = last_blog_publish_date.strftime("%Y")
current_blog_url = last_blog_publish_date.strftime("%Y%m%d") + '-tru.json.txt'
#current_blog_url = 'TRU_' + last_blog_publish_date.strftime("%m%d%y") + '.txt'
publish_date = last_blog_publish_date.strftime("%d-%m-%Y")

properties.description: Do a test through w while loop to identify the URL_ID of the latest published Weekly Roundup

actions.name: Condition Block
actions.title: Check if this Friday Talos Roundup blog has been published

properties.description: This condition block checks whether the Talos Roundup Blog has been published. If yes (the blog has been published) then set the current_blog_uri with the URI that gives a successful HTTPS GET call and break the While loop in order to proceed with the investigation.
properties.display_name: Check if this Friday Talos Roundup blog has been published

properties.description:
Take this road of the workflow if the "Do an HTTPS GET call at Talos Roundup blog URI" activity execution returns Succeded = false.

This condition branch increases the number of retries by 1 and then sleeps for 1 hour before going through the main While loop to check whether the Talos Roundup blog URI has become available in the meantime.  However, if the max_number_iteration is reached, a message is sent out and the workflow terminates.

actions.name: Condition Block
actions.title: Have we achieved the max number of retries?

properties.description: This condition block checks whether the max_number_iteration has been reached
properties.display_name: Have we achieved the max number of retries?

blocks.name: Condition Branch
blocks.title: No, then increment number of retry iteration

properties.description: We take this road in case the current retry_iteration variable is less than the max_number_retry_iteration variable (an input variable, by default set to 24)
properties.display_name: No, then increment number of retry iteration

properties.description: Simply increases the retry__iteration variable by 1

blocks.name: Condition Branch
blocks.title: Yes, max number reached, send messages and exit workflow

properties.description:
We take this road if the retry_iteration equals max_number_retry_iterations. This means that we have reached the max number of retries for checking whether the Talos Roundup blog URI has become available in the meantime.

An informational message is built and sent out through email and/or Webex Teams, the the workflow is terminated.
properties.display_name: Yes, max number reached, send messages and exit workflow

properties.description: In case the "Do an HTTPS GET call at Talos Roundup blog URI" gives a Succeded = true, this means the Talos Roundup blog URI is available, and the JSON file can be downloaded and processed ahead through the workflow. In this case, the variable current_blog_uri is set with the successful URI and then the while loop is broken to proceed with the investigation.

actions.name: Group
actions.title: Send notification (email/webex teams) investigation has started

properties.description:
An html message to be sent via email is created. This message will inform the customer that the Investigation has started together with the list of most prevalent threats (and description) that Talos has identified during the current week. The message will have the following text:

"*** This is an informational message ***  Weekly Talos Roundup automated investigation has started ( <X> threats have been reported in the blog). More information will follow during the investigation. Talos has published IOCs related to the following most prevalent threats observed during this week (publish date: <publish_date>): 

<follows list of Threats and description>

More information will follow during the investigation. Talos has published IOCs related to the following most prevalent threats observed during this week (publish date: <publish_date>): 

<follows list of Threats and description>

properties.subject: Talos Roundup Investigation started

actions.name: For Each
actions.title: For Each Threat in the table get IOCs

properties.description:
For each threat published from Talos (threat name and description stored in the local table variable signature_table), the following tasks are carried out:

1. Extract IOCs (Domains, IP addresses, File/MUTEX/REGISTRY hashes) from the JSON file.

2. Populate the local string variable indicators with all IOCs found.

3.  Parse IOCs in SecureX Threat Response.

4.  Enrich the parsed Observables

5.  Determine Domains within the Observables that may have a Clean Verdict. This domains will not be investigated since they would alert Targets related to clean domain observables.

6. For each module that has answered back through the enrichment call, process the provided data to identify Targets. If Target found, then an email and/or Webex Teams message is sent.

8. Target found? If yes, then create a Casebook case.
properties.display_name: For Each Threat in the table get IOCs

properties.display_name: Set ioc_value variable with IOC value

properties.description:
Check for the Verdict of the provided domain. A Verdict is chosen from all of the Judgements on that Observable which have not yet expired. The highest priority Judgement becomes the active verdict. If there is more than one Judgement with that priority, then Clean disposition has priority over all others, then Malicious disposition, and so on down to Unknown. 

The  disposition_name field <string> is returned:  {Clean, Malicious, Suspicious, Common, Unknown}.

properties.description:
Observe an Entity - return Sightings from your modules about any of the above entity types. Sighting - an observation of an observable. For example, an endpoint detecting a file hash detected on a filesystem, or on the network by a firewall.

In this case, we are enriching all the security Observables denoting the current Threat.

properties.body:
SecureX Threat Response has found out that there are Targets in your environment related to the threat $activity.definition_activity_01IWCZNX9WMZK1f7D3JREjlkNfdgTKhDgDw.input.source_array[@].signature_name$

Module: $activity.definition_activity_01H09MMM0066W0Qj3WgfQQivlYfQnViYJGl.input.source_array[@].module$

Found sightings: $activity.definition_activity_01H09N4KGSUTM1URrluQqHI3j5Aw2VGu62z.output.row_count$

Target details (displaying only the first target/sighting): $activity.definition_activity_01H09N4KGSUTM1URrluQqHI3j5Aw2VGu62z.output.read_table_from_json[0].observables$

Time: $activity.definition_activity_01H09N4KGSUTM1URrluQqHI3j5Aw2VGu62z.output.read_table_from_json[0].observed_time$

A summary casebook will be created in SecureX when the investigation related to the threat $activity.definition_activity_01IWCZNX9WMZK1f7D3JREjlkNfdgTKhDgDw.input.source_array[@].signature_name$ has been completed. The casebook link and ID will be communicated in a subsequent communication. Please connect to your tenant at https://securex.eu.security.cisco.com/ and launch an investigation with the security observables - denoting the threat that may have potentially impacted your environment, and review the outcome for further analysis.
properties.subject: Found targets - $activity.definition_activity_01IWCZNX9WMZK1f7D3JREjlkNfdgTKhDgDw.input.source_array[@].signature_name$
